title: CoCoOn: Cloud Computing Ontology for IaaS Price and Performance Comparison

author: Armin Haller, Research School of Information Sciences and Engineering, Australian National University

segmentation: So this is obviously work by my student.
I'm just in a supervisory panel actually, so the student is called me Runner saying she is now an industry we lost to the industry she's working on cloud computing.
Of course, some cloud computing company has picked up.
She is just waiting for her PhD to finish and that work was part of her PhD thesis, just a small part, and it's as mentioned, publishing the resource track.
So it is a domain ontology and I don't want to really bore you with the domain itself, so I want to try to just motivate why we built this ontology and what you could use this ontology for.

Is quite a long standing problem infrastructure as a service is quite a old established concept in cloud computing and already in 2013 there were over 426 computes and storage service providers, so that's the Amazons and the Microsofts and Googles.
So 426 of those in 2013 and with 11,000 locations.
And that's about six years ago, so it certainly has just grown.
And the problem is with this infrastructure service is that they have non standardized naming conventions.

So the way you talk about the CPU or storage or network the way you talk about the virtualization technology, the way you talk about the service level agreements and the billing model and the location is all using different semantics, different labels and it makes a comparison between these different services very hard.
And in fact, it's also probably in the interest of the service providers to make this comparison really hard.
So what what my student?

It was already a while ago, a couple of years ago she developed the first version of an ontology that tried to give you a meta model for services for cloud computing services, and she called that kokuin the cloud computing ontology, and this paper is basically an extension and new version of this ontology incorporating some of the changes that have happened in the last five years.
Since 2013, when she did the first version of this ontology, the changes that happened.
